ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I pursued an independent interest in the intersections between Greek tragedy and political theory. As the course progressed, I developed a research question with Professor Schillinger that gave our readings and discussions more focus. The study was most valuable as my first experience with a longer process of writing, and having rounds of feedback was invaluable to developing my writing skills with prolonged engagement with an argument or idea. Having a say in the specific readings that I would do and having a bigger hand in directing the discussion also felt like an important next step in my studies.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This was an excellent course: as always, Professor Schillinger pushed my understanding of the texts we read further, and we explored some challenging and exciting questions about empire and the function of tragedy (pity/fear). We read a mix of different materials with clear objectives behind each meeting.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: AbsolutelyI was very lucky to have the chance to experience such a focused and self-directed course; I don't think it would be overexaggerating to say that this is a life-shaping experience. It was more challenging than a seminar because you are so accountable and the conversation depends more on your ideas, but I would recommend it without hesitation.
